title: 105_hr4290
content: The "Gun Buy Back Partnership Grant Act of 1998" aims to reduce gun violence by assisting State and local law enforcement in conducting community gun buy back programs. This initiative is driven by findings that highlight the high number of gun-related deaths in the United States, emphasizing the need to address the prevalence of guns in American households. The "Gun Buy Back Partnership Grant Act of 1998" authorizes grants for States and local governments to run community gun buy back programs. Funds must be used solely for this purpose, with a minimum allocation of 0.50 percent of the total appropriation per qualifying entity. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance is restricted from providing excessive amounts under this Act. Under the "Gun Buy Back Partnership Grant Act of 1998," the Bureau of Justice Assistance is limited to providing a qualifying State or local government with no more than 5 percent of the total appropriation for the fiscal year. Grants cannot cover more than 50 percent of the cost of a community gun buy back program, unless waived by the Director due to fiscal hardship. Preferential consideration is given to applications from jurisdictions that will destroy all guns received in the program. The "Gun Buy Back Partnership Grant Act of 1998" limits the Bureau of Justice Assistance to providing a State or local government with up to 5% of the total appropriation for the fiscal year. Grants cannot exceed 50% of the cost of a community gun buy back program, unless waived by the Director. A community gun buy back program that donates inoperable guns with historic significance to a museum will be treated the same as one that destroys all guns received. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS. State and local governments must submit applications to the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance to request grants under this Act. Applications must be signed by the respective chief executives and contain required information. Grants can be renewed annually, and regulations must be established within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will create regulations for implementing the Act, outlining necessary information and submission requirements for grant applications from States and local governments. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "community gun buy back program" refers to a program where State or local law enforcement authorities purchase or accept donations of guns from individuals. The term "gun" means a firearm as defined in section 921(a)(3) of title 18, United States Code. "Qualifying State or unit of local government" refers to a State or unit of local government that meets the grant application requirements under this Act. The term "State" includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS ON AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $15,000,000 authorized for grants to the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance annually.
